2024 JAN 15 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- New research on applied sciences is the subject of a new report. According to news reporting originating from Zhengzhou, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "As global warming progresses, forest fires have become more frequent, leading to the destruction of forest biodiversity and consequently affecting Earth's ecosystems and human living conditions."


Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from North China University of Water Resources and Electric Power: "The ability to predict the long-term trend of forest fires holds significant value for fire prevention and management. In Yunnan Province, China, a region rich in forest resources, this study utilized temperature, average annual rainfall, relative humidity, and wind speed data from 1991 to 2021. We forecasted forest fires using the stepwise regression and autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) model, incorporating the collected forest fire data. The findings reveal a negative correlation between rainfall and forest fire incidence, whereas wind speed exhibited a positive correlation. The ARIMA model forecasts a cyclical trend in fires from 2022 to 2033, with considerable fluctuations in the number of fires, notably in 2027 and 2033."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The projected affected area is anticipated to show a marked increase from 2028 onwards. This research not only provides a novel methodology for forecasting forest fires but also lays a scientific foundation for the development of future fire prevention and mitigation strategies."
For more information on this research see: Predictive Modeling of Forest Fires in Yunnan Province: An Integration of ARIMA and Stepwise Regression Analysis. Applied Sciences, 2023,14(1). (Applied Sciences - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/applsci). The publisher for Applied Sciences is MDPI AG.

2022 JUL 27 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ivy League Daily News -- Fresh data on Science are presented in a new report. According to news originating from New Haven, Connecticut, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "In the era of single-cell sequencing, there is a growing need to extract insights from data with clustering methods. Here, inspired by forest fire dynamics, the authors devise an algorithm that can cluster single-cell data with minimal prior assumptions and can compute a non-parametric posterior probability for each data point."


Financial support for this research came from National Institutes of Health (NIH) - USA.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Yale University, "In the era of single-cell sequencing, there is a growing need to extract insights from data with clustering methods. Here, we introduce Forest Fire Clustering, an efficient and interpretable method for cell-type discovery from single-cell data. Forest Fire Clustering makes minimal prior assumptions and, different from current approaches, calculates a non-parametric posterior probability that each cell is assigned a cell-type label. These posterior distributions allow for the evaluation of a label confidence for each cell and enable the computation of 'label entropies', highlighting transitions along developmental trajectories. Furthermore, we show that Forest Fire Clustering can make robust, inductive inferences in an online-learning context and can readily scale to millions of cells. Finally, we demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art clustering approaches on diverse benchmarks of simulated and experimental data."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Overall, Forest Fire Clustering is a useful tool for rare cell type discovery in large-scale single-cell analysis."
For more information on this research see: Forest Fire Clustering for Single-cell Sequencing Combines Iterative Label Propagation With Parallelized Monte Carlo Simulations. urn:contentItem:6DX7-P6K3-RRXF-R4NV-00000-00Achieving Organizationality in Large-Scale Crises: A Comparative Case Study on the Communicative Constitution of Spontaneous Volunteer Collectives2025-11-15T08:31:48Z2025-11-15T08:31:48ZLexisNexisPg. 104-128Achieving Organizationality in Large-Scale Crises: A Comparative Case Study on the Communicative Constitution of Spontaneous Volunteer Collectives

Data Availability StatementThe data are not publicly available due to ethical, legal, and data security concerns.

Declaration of Conflicting InterestsThe author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

FundingThe author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: Research reported in this publication was supported by the German Federal Ministry of Education and Research (PRAKOS, ref. CAU 13N13326).

ORCID iDChristine Carius https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3264-8931

Supplemental MaterialSupplemental material for this article is available online.

Christine CariusJan GrawCarsten SchultzABSTRACT

Many large-scale crises require rapid responses from spontaneous volunteers (SVs). The more effective the way in which volunteers develop organizationality, the better they are able to coordinate individual activities, and the better they can cope with demands imposed by a disaster. However, we currently know too little about how SV collectives emerge and develop organizationality in the context of crises. We, therefore, explore organizationality’s emerging phases and determinants by grounding our study on the “communication constitutes organizations” research stream, that is, the four flows (4 F) model. In our qualitative analysis based on semi-structured interviews, as well as (social) media data from five large-scale crises in Germany, we identify the role of space, symbols, and support (3 S), and their effects as enablers of legitimacy and collective identity. By complementing the 4 F model, we contribute to “communication constitutes organizations” research and draw implications for managing loose SV collectives in practice.

FULL TEXTIntroduction

Spontaneous volunteers (SVs) respond rapidly to large-scale crises to address urgent needs. Spontaneous volunteering occurs frequently when citizens perceive that the formally responsible relief organizations do not meet all needs. It is characterized by an unplanned and “learning by doing” way (Simsa et al., 2019; Twigg & Mosel, 2017; Whittaker et al., 2015). Important examples include responses to natural disasters, such as hurricane Katrina (Butts et al., 2012; Kusumasari, 2012), and floods in Europe, such as those in Germany in 2013 and in the United Kingdom (Albris, 2018; Harris et al., 2017). Spontaneous volunteering also occurs during social crises, such as the refugee crisis in 2015 (Kaltenbrunner & Renzl, 2019; Simsa et al., 2019), the crisis during the COVID-19 pandemic (Burke et al., 2023; Tu, 2022), and, currently, the crisis caused by Ukrainian refugees wanting to escape the war in their country (Bang Carlsen et al., 2023). Common to these examples is the crucial and at the same time challenging nature of spontaneous volunteering, which is influenced by diverse cultures and approaches among relief forces, volunteers, and emerging volunteer collectives, potentially impeding relief efforts (Kaufhold & Reuter, 2016; Nahkur et al., 2022).

However, we know too little about the process of how SV collectives emerge from individuals, whether and how SVs establish structures in the context of large-scale crises and coordinate their work as part of inter-organizational collaborations, and which boundary conditions affect this process (Massa & O’Mahony, 2021; Schoeneborn et al., 2022). The SVs’ lack of authority can lead to additional conflicts within the collective and with relief forces (Barbour & Manly, 2016; Schmidt et al., 2017). Thus, SV collectives require a form of legitimacy for effective operation within a crisis context. Legitimacy can be increased by having a collective identity and being recognizable as an organization (Kavanagh et al., 2021). Still, our understanding of how SV collectives establish their authority, and how others, such as relief forces, legitimate them without being perceived as an organization, is limited (Nissen et al., 2022). Hence, we turn to the concept of organizationality, which helps us understand how organization and organizational forms emerge from other forms of sociality (Dobusch & Schoeneborn, 2015; Schoeneborn et al., 2022). Our research questions are therefore:

Research Question 1: How do emerging SV collectives achieve organization-ality?

Research Question 2: How do emerging SV collectives gain legitimacy in the inter-organizational context of crises response?

We utilize and extend the four flows (4 F) model (McPhee & Zaug, 2000) to explore how organizationality emerges and shed light on organizationality’s more pronounced effects on legitimacy and collective identity. We use a multiple case study design with five large-scale crises, namely, heavy rain events, storm events, floods, and the refugee crisis, to examine the emergent organizationality of spontaneous volunteering. The term crisis is often used for man-made disruptive events, as opposed to disasters, which are perceived to have natural causes (Shaluf et al., 2003). Yet, many presumed natural disasters are not only due to natural causes but have also become more frequent due to human-induced climate change (Chmutina & von Meding, 2019). We will therefore use the term crisis throughout this article. Our data set is based on interview-generated insights and enriched with social media communication, data from newspaper articles, published video material, and official reports.

Our resulting contribution is fourfold. First, by analyzing how communication flows evolve, we complement existing studies by enhancing their understanding of organizational beginnings in fluid collectives. Second, we add to the emerging literature on organizationality by showing that space, symbol, and support (3 S) are crucial for developing a collective’s identity and legitimacy. Third, by distinguishing between organizationality’s three development phases, we highlight the 4 F model’s temporal dimension. Based on our results, we develop an enhanced model of achieving organizationality, which could guide future research and practice, even beyond the context of coping with crises like, for example, in the context of patient self-help organizations. Fourth, from a managerial perspective, our findings contribute to a new collaborative approach between SV collectives and relief forces: Instead of assimilating and dominating SVs, relief forces can support the SVs’ emerging organizationality and collaborate successfully.

Theoretical BackgroundVolunteering and SV Collectives

Research on volunteering distinguishes between formal and informal volunteering (Lee & Brudney, 2012). It has largely focused on formal volunteering and topics like volunteer management and coordination (Brudney & Meijs, 2009; Studer & von Schnurbein, 2013), satisfaction, and turnover (Hustinx, 2010; Kulik et al., 2016). Informal volunteering is defined as a short, single response to a crisis and entails the unstructured contribution of a volunteer’s time to help friends, neighbors, or the community (Dean, 2022). Spontaneous volunteering is considered an informal, ad hoc way of helping during or after a crisis as an immediate response to emerging needs (Simsa et al., 2019; Whittaker et al., 2015). Often, but not necessarily, SV collectives emerge in this process. Twigg and Mosel (2017) characterized emergent groups of SVs as “individual citizens coming together to deal collectively with disasters, forming new and informal groups to do so” (p. 445). SVs have been the focus of recent research on disaster management, volunteerism, and organizing, exploring how SVs co-create services with professionals (Nielsen, 2022; Thomas et al., 2021) and how organizing occurs under the auspices of civil society organizations (Kornberger et al., 2019; Simsa et al., 2019).

Interorganizational Collaboration Between Relief Forces and Spontaneous Volunteer Collectives

Responding to a large-scale crisis involves a variety of organizations collaborating across organizational boundaries (Kalkman & de Waard, 2017). Relief organizations, such as emergency services and fire departments, are high-reliability organizations that operate in fast-paced and highly complex systems (Roberts & Rousseau, 1989). Two characteristics of high-reliability organizations are that they are hierarchical and that they have a common understanding of teamwork (Baker et al., 2006). In contrast, SVs do not rely on formal structures or procedures (Dynes, 1970; Quarantelli, 1988). Owing to SVs’ perceived lack of structure, discipline, and, subsequently, legitimacy (Majchrzak & More, 2011), disaster management research has a tendency to consider them the “other” side of professional disaster management (Strandh & Eklund, 2017).

Relief forces face uncertainty when they try to collaborate with SVs and fear additional complications if they fail to coordinate SVs. Relief forces may therefore refuse to consider SVs as a viable partner in crisis response (Daddoust et al., 2021; Twigg & Mosel, 2017). The tension that arises from the phenomenon of SV as a potentially beneficial additional resource, while at the same time posing a risk of dangerous behavior, has led research to conclude that relief forces face an “inclusion/exclusion paradox” (Harris et al., 2017; Krogh & Lo, 2023).

The persistent call to integrate “unorganized” SVs into relief organizations therefore resulted in “pre-registration” or “integration” tasks that are expected to be fulfilled by relief forces (Koolen-Maas et al., 2022; Skar et al., 2016). Current research also suggests that SVs need to adapt to relief forces’ underlying mechanisms and structures (Raisio et al., 2022). From a managerial perspective, this approach might disregard the benefits of highly motivated SVs that accomplish adequate crisis response in an unconventional manner.

Organizationality and Spontaneous Volunteer Collectives

Communication constitutes organization (CCO) research conceptualizes organizations as an interconnected communication process (McPhee & Zaug, 2000). By favoring organizations’ emergent and fluid character, CCO, and specifically the concept of organizationality, is well suited to examine looser and fluid forms of organization, which may lack structure or membership boundaries, such as SV collectives (Dobusch & Schoeneborn, 2015). Organizationality helps transcend the binary distinction between organization and non-organization, allowing a more gradual differentiation in which social collectives may unfold higher or lower degrees of organizationality (Schoeneborn et al., 2022; Smith, 2022). In this regard, literature distinguishes three layers of organizationality: interconnected decision-making, collective actorhood, and identity claims (Dobusch & Schoeneborn, 2015). Degrees of organizationality are thereby either achieved as an intentional act or as a “side-product” (Schoeneborn et al., 2022, p. 143).

Organizational research has focused on collectives exhibiting organizationality in non-crisis settings, such as people in co-working spaces (Blagoev et al., 2019) or bike commuters (Wilhoit & Kisselburgh, 2015). It has identified space, understood as “material assemblage,” and technology as contributors to the organizing practices of emerging organizational forms (Cnossen & Bencherki, 2019; Endrissat & Islam, 2022; Smith, 2022). In this regard, Burke et al. (2023) revealed how emergent collectives during the pandemic used spatial mapping and partitioning to manage online–offline translations and overcome initial chaos. Still, achieving or degrading organizationality in large-scale crisis settings is not well-researched.

The 4 F Model

One of the three main schools of thought in CCO is the 4 F model, which is described as a template for detecting, diagnosing, and assessing new organizational phenomena (McPhee & Zaug, 2000). According to the model, organization occurs at the intersection of four distinct communication flows, namely membership negotiation, activity coordination, self-structuring, and institutional positioning, which need to be sufficiently closely interrelated to actually create an organization (McPhee & Zaug, 2000). Membership negotiation comprises communication events, which encompass recruitment, inclusion, exclusion, commitment, and identification. Activity coordination comprises discussions and documents relating to the planning and controlling of operations. Self-reflexive structuring utilizes an organization’s awareness of itself and comprises organizational policies and processes of changes or stabilization. In contrast to activity coordination, self-structuring is a communication process between organizational role-holders and others. Institutional positioning comprises any communication activity that positions an organization in relation to other entities. This involves both the creation of an identity and the development and maintenance of a specific role within the interorganizational system. Recent research has used the 4 F model to illustrate the design and maintenance of short-term organizations, such as the Trump University (Iverson et al., 2022). The 4 F model has also been applied to the crisis context to offer a communicative explanation of adaptive capacity in the aftermath of a wildfire (Jahn & Johansson, 2018).

Motivated by the “black box” of emerging organizationality in fluid collectives, this paper explores the emerging organizationality of SV collectives during crisis response and makes three contributions: First, it helps balance the understanding of spontaneous volunteering’s challenges, by including the perspectives of SVs, relief forces, and other stakeholders. Second, applying a communication-centered framework contributes insights into the emergence of organizationality. Third, it allows for a novel approach whereby relief forces “deal” with SVs without assimilating and dominating them, but by facilitating the emergence of organizationality in SV collectives instead.

MethodCase Selection

We employ a multiple case study design (Yin, 2017), based on a rich empirical data set of five cases concerning large-scale crises in Germany. Following a cross-case comparison approach, we aim to understand the factors that enable loose SVs to achieve organizationality and legitimacy in different settings of large-scale crises. Thus, to identify and select suitable cases to answer our research questions, we defined the following inclusion criteria: (a) a large part of the society and the infrastructure being impaired, (b) the local relief forces’ resources being insufficient to cope with the situation, therefore requiring the involvement of supra-local relief forces, (c) supra-regional media presence, (d) at least one SV collective emerging, (e) the case studies being regionally distributed, and (f) access to data within 12 months of the crisis. This led to five cases of large-scale crises in the analysis. Two cases (Case 1 and Case 2) happened 12 months before our data were collected, which meant that we accessed them retrospectively. The other three cases (Case 3, Case 4, and Case 5) occurred during the research project period and were collected immediately after the completion of the immediate crisis management activities. Three cases are related to a large-scale crisis caused by natural hazards: a storm (Case 1), flooding due to heavy rain (Case 2), and river flooding (Case 3), while two cases address the refugee crisis in two cities (Case 4 and Case 5). Data Set

Our study focuses on the experiences and perceptions of volunteers, as well as the perspectives of other organizations involved, such as emergency responders or city officials. Therefore, we generated a rich empirical data set comprising 30 semi-structured interviews and additional material comprising social media communication, official documents, press releases, and documentary video material.

Interviews were conducted with representatives of both the SVs and the disaster relief organizations and also with other stakeholders involved, such as the city representatives and authorities. We conducted the interviews using a semi-structured approach, which allowed us to collect a priori-derived questions and to remain flexible regarding the interviewees’ individual experiences and focus topics. We conducted group and individual informant interviews. Table 2 provides an overview of the interview type and additional materials used per case.

Slightly adapted interview guides were prepared for our interviews with the SVs and relief forces. Both comprised three main parts: (a) their perception of the situation, (b) the emergence of organizationality, and (c) their collaboration with others and the tensions experienced in respect of others. Interviews with other organizations’ representatives focused on their perception of SVs’ activities, collaboration, and the relevant relief operations. We used snowball sampling to target relief forces involved with the volunteers across roles and levels of authority (e.g., senior management fire department and middle management police department) and with volunteers with different roles (initiators, coordinators, one-time helpers). Owing to this methodology and to ensure the handling of a large amount of data, the study reached theoretical saturation with varying numbers of interviews per case. The interviews lasted 45 to 90 min and were recorded and subsequently transcribed.

Secondary data (e.g., newspaper articles, press releases, media content, and reports; see also Supplementary Material 1) were also included in our analysis to complement and compare with the interviewees’ perceptions. In addition, we held a 2-day workshop with volunteers (Cases 1, 2, 4, and 5) and relief forces (Cases 3 and 4) to jointly “backtrack” the cases (Gioia et al., 2013) and discuss and validate our preliminary findings.

Data Analysis

We used the MAXQDA qualitative analysis software to support our coding procedures. Two of the authors coded and analyzed the interview transcripts independently to ensure the results’ reliability. In the event of differing interpretations of the data, the authors returned to the interview data, discussed the discrepancies with a third project researcher, and formed a consensus that ultimately resulted in a list of first-order categories (Miles & Huberman, 1994). We chose a combination of inductive and deductive coding procedures followed by a multi-step process. In the first step, using inductive coding, the transcribed text phrases were open-coded, retaining the informants’ original expressions such that the first-order level codes remained true to the originals (Mayring, 2015). Thereafter, in the second step, axial coding was applied to identify the links between first-order concepts. These first-order concepts were grouped into higher-order themes. Finally, we identified the relationships between the themes and established the aggregate dimensions. Supplementary materials 2 and 3 present our deductive coding operationalization and code aggregation diagram.

Cross-Case Comparison

Following a cross-case approach, we started analyzing by coding the first two cases (Case 1, Case 2). The analysis focused on identifying key themes in the data, based on their influence and repetition in the cases. In parallel, by identifying numerous events and practices related to achieving organizationality, we compiled the chronology of each collective’s emergence, based on relief forces’ and volunteers’ descriptions of critical events. The chronology was confirmed using social media and media data. This, with reference to the literature, resulted in a detailed representation of the 4 F. On this basis, we started analyzing the other three cases’ data (Case 3, Case 4, and Case 5). In doing so, we focused on the 4 F’s previously revealed patterns and on identifying additional factors that could complement the 4 F model.

To validate and triangulate our data-oriented analysis based on the respondents’ individual experiences, we used supplementary data (Eisenhardt, 1989). No substantial inconsistencies were found. However, these additional data specifically allowed us to understand the evolution of emerging organizationality and to associate the key activities with organizational and organizationality development. Based on these case-centered approaches, the next activity was to contrast the data by looking for emerging patterns between the cases and characterizations of the quintain (Stake, 2006). Finally, we reflected on our understanding of how organizationality emerged in the five cases by referring to the literature. In our final analytical process, we examined the extent to which additional factors contributed to the emerging organizationality. We analyzed the sequence of practices and flows, focusing on the identified incidents and resulting changes in the structure and processes. By iterating between the data, CCO theorizing, and volunteering research, we developed a model of fluid social collectives achieving organizationality and eventually emerging organizations.

Findings

We first present our findings with examples of the 4 F in the cases.

Outlining the flows over time (e.g., by social media posts), we found that some flows, such as activity coordination, are traceable from the very beginning of the process, while other flows, such as institutional positioning, only become more visible later in the organization's development. We suggest differentiating three phases of emergence. Subsequently, by considering the turning points of the development and the complementary factors relevant for achieving organizationality, we explain how the 3 S all fuel the transition from one phase to another. The findings conclude by detailing how increasing organizationality is reflected in the development of collective identity and how this results in legitimization within the interorganizational context.

The Four Flows AppliedActivity Coordination

Initially, individual volunteers provided help in their immediate environment and used social media, especially Facebook, to communicate and coordinate. Coordination in Cases 1 and 2 involved sharing information about which sites to prioritize, who had access to needed materials (1: saws, 2: pumps, buckets), and how to receive and distribute donations. In Case 3, SVs coordinated shelter, child care, animal care, travel arrangements, and food supply. Typical activities in Cases 4 and 5 were arrangements for who would come to the station when, what donations were needed, where donations would be collected, and so on.

Within a short time, the Facebook groups experienced an enormous amount of traffic, with several thousand people in each group, resulting in miscommunication, a lack of prioritization, and the misallocation of resources. Having different people leading without the necessary information to coordinate, leads to conflicting mandates and, ultimately, chaos. All respondents referred to the chaos of the first hours and days. Consequently, the individual volunteers’ rather inefficient attempts to coordinate the activity dominated the first phase. Toby in Case 1 explains: “Then . . . we had this big group [. . .] and there was so much information, you couldn’t really filter it all” (Interview 1.1, p. 6).

Self-Reflexive Structuring

The respondents consistently described the structuring phase following the initial chaos. For example, traces of self-reflexive structuring dominated the social media communication. In Case 1, Mary, one of the Facebook group’s members, created a WhatsApp group comprising what she called “team leaders,” who would each lead their district team. Toby recalls, “We called them team leader, a totally stupid name, because we had no hierarchy” (Interview 1.1 p. 12).

Not all efforts to structure were ultimately successful as this quote from Case 2 shows: On the second day [. . .] it crystallized within the group that there was a lady who was very involved and tried to organize a bit [. . .], [. . .] in district north, for example, if someone needed [support]-[she would say] ‘come, we send someone from the southern district.’ That was a completely different side. [. . .] even though, in district north, three were registered [. . .]. So totally confusing (Interview 2.1, p. 6–7).

After Day 2, the volunteers in Case 2 controlled the flow of information on Facebook by having a moderator remove posts featuring sensitive information and by establishing a system that allowed the organizers to control access to this information.

It is also possible to trace the internal structure through the terminology applied. There is a linguistic distinction between the core center’s team and the volunteers working outside at this time. For example, Lilly, in the core team in Case 2, answered the phone in a live video documentary: “I am irritated with such questions, because we are the contact team here and not the helpers” (Dassel & Gersch, 2015, Min 39 Sec 29). Lilly clearly referred to an internal structure with which the caller should have been familiar.

In Case 3, although the administrators created the group to coordinate the efforts and thereby create an initial structure, the helpers suggested a different or more elaborate structure: “People, finding one’s way through your confusing homepage and the laborious registration are both very inefficient!” (Facebook post 8498). The administrators followed the suggestions and set up files as public documents, in which anyone could post their requests for help or offers of help, which were arranged according to their topics. In addition, they provided a document explaining the rules in terms of the communication and conduct. This division of labor between helpers and coordinating helpers characterizes the ongoing structuring processes. A (partial) organizational awareness emerges and forms the basis for organizational learning. As a result, inefficiencies are reduced.

Membership Negotiation

In Case 3, the Facebook group creators implemented a registration process right from the start. Volunteers had to “ask” for admittance to the closed group, which the organizers granted. In turn, the members thanked the organizers for their efforts, thereby creating a power imbalance between the organizers and the members. Having each joining member acknowledge its authority, legitimized the organizational structure, which dominated the organization’s institutional positioning. In Case 5, our interviewees described how they organized the new members’ instruction process: “When we organized our collective’s (new) people, we always tried to have them meet on the spot at a certain time and have someone there who was noticeably in charge of everyone” (Interview 5.2, p. 2).

Administrators in Case 3 managed the content of the Facebook group’s conversations by advising which communications should end. When they encountered off-topic or inappropriate communication, they announced this communication would be terminated if the members did not end the topic themselves: “PLEASE, finish this thread, otherwise I’ll have to end it. Thank you!” (Facebook post 7,660). While the helpers moved through the affected places equipped with shovels, the coordinators took on the task of coordinating with the emergency forces, communicating the need for help, distributing tools if required, and coordinating food and drink for the helpers. The organization took care of its members and the SVs’ performance gained more consistency and reliability.

The communication reflected the evolved structure; the boundaries of the “team” were made very clear by listing the names of the administrative team and using a general designation for the others, such as “all those who help,” “helpers,” or “citizens,” to guide those who receive the coordinating messages. By means of this linguistic separation of the helpers and the organizers, the resulting structure gained authority and was reproduced. Identity-enforcing narratives, recognizable clothing, and further established routines, that is, to welcome helpers, increased organizational awareness.

Institutional Positioning

In Case 1, the city banned its citizens from its playgrounds, parks, and other public spaces, due to the risk of falling trees and branches. The SV collective approached the authorities as a “group” to obtain permission to ignore this ban. By allowing this, the authorities acknowledged the group’s organizational character. In Case 2, the strong emphasis on the SV collective’s identity was based on its ability to complete tasks faster or even better than the formal organizations could. Lilly recalled a dispute with a representative of the relief forces: He wanted to demonstrate [his superior knowledge] by saying, ‘Do you know what a high-performance pump is?’ I said, ‘Yes, pumping x liters per minute.’ ‘And why do you have six?’ I said, we have the support of [company] (Interview 2.1 p. 30).

Within a week, the core team’s volunteers appeared in a photo in a local newspaper, wearing similar clothes as a uniform, which symbolized their professionalism, discipline, and unity just as the relief forces’ uniform did. The media and the city readily offered the core team’s phone number, thereby presenting the SV collective as a legitimate organization. The live video documentary shows Lilly answering another phone call with the welcoming words: “SV (group name), Lilly here, hi” (Dassel & Gersch, 2015, sec. 40:41). She positioned herself as an organization spokesperson, thereby establishing the organization’s existence by means of communicating and asserting its legitimate agency.

In Case 3, the SVs positioned themselves as supporters of the rescue forces and, as such, the relief organizations gave them a telephone number and a table in the provision room.

In Cases 4 and 5, the persons that the relief forces perceived as SV representatives were invited to participate in the briefing sessions, thereby granting them external agency well before the site volunteers did so. This involvement provided the SVs with access to up-to-date information, allowing them to coordinate their activities accordingly. The volunteers learned that if those “representatives” coordinated them, they were more likely to achieve their objective of providing meaningful assistance on site. This development resulted in their steadily growing willingness to have these representatives coordinate them, which then led to their role being legitimized and a full organizational consciousness arose.

Cross-Case Comparison

We identified all four communication flows in all the cases. While structuring and institutional positioning became, over time, apparent in Cases 1, 2, 4, and 5, it could be traced from the very beginning in Case 3.

Case 3 differs from the others, in that the goal of the Facebook group’s founders was clearly to organize the SVs to support the rescue forces.

By setting the rules of restricted access to the group, by presenting a structure, and through the positioning within the interorganizational context, the administrators had an organization in mind. Nevertheless, it is also evident in Case 3 that the members question and improve the structure to facilitate the activity’s coordination. “Could you not add the current list to the fixed area every day, otherwise it will soon be lost in the depths and many will not scroll down that far, especially the NM is almost impossible to find :) :)” (Facebook post 0036).

The Emergence of Organizationality in Three Phases

We identified three distinguishable emergence phases determined by their characteristics and practices. Figure 1 provides an overview.

Figure 1.

Organizationality’s Three Development Phases.

This evolutionary process does not reflect a defined chronological sequence, but instead indicates a tendency toward developmental stages. First, individuals coordinate their activities without any organizational awareness, often by using social media to communicate their needs. Subsequently, they misallocate their resources due to their limited coordination. To counter these misallocations, physical structures, such as coordination centers that bundle and pass on information in a targeted way, emerge in the second phase. In these coordination centers, volunteers establish structures and processes that potentially lead to resources being used more effectively and efficiently. The structuring phase is not a self-contained phase. Instead, it shows a tendency for groups to develop from individual activities to coordinated structures based on the division of labor, defined processes, and routines. The processes and structures become more and more differentiated as they progress. An attitude of trying things, discarding or improving processes, and of setting up new labor division models was maintained throughout the relief process.

In the third phase, those in the central structures gain authority and legitimacy within the group by preventing the misallocation of resources. By using their legitimacy, these people (re)-design processes, establish rules for organizational discourses and care for the group members’ needs. The interviewees repeatedly described how, once processes and structures were established, the group’s sense of “we” also strengthened. With increasingly elaborated membership processes, the group’s positioning regarding the unaffiliated helpers (those outside the volunteer collective) and the authorities became apparent, which, in turn, promoted their external legitimacy. A clearer picture emerged of what constitutes the SV collective and in what form, and how this organization positions itself within the social context.

Extending the 4 F Model: The Role of Space, Symbol, and Support

In a second inductive step, we analyzed the interview data—triangulated with additional documents—and the insight gained from the workshop to identify the factors contributing to the increase in organizationality and thereby complementing the 4 F model. We identified the particular role that space, symbols, and support play.

Space

Digital space, specifically Facebook, was used as the central communication and coordination platform. Digital spaces allowed the organization’s boundaries to be blurry, which facilitated membership negotiations and, initially, activity coordination. Facebook groups’ specific nature also supported the structuring efforts. Our cases demonstrate that this platform-based authorization concept enables SVs to enforce the organization structure by taking control of its discourses and by starting membership negotiations.

In some cases, extensive sets of rules were developed for communication within the group. In Cases 3 and 4, the organizers and administrators interrupted or deleted communication, which they believed did not belong to the topic or did not correspond to the organization’s values. They announced these measures and emphasized their roles, therefore legitimizing these specific activities. The group confirmed the existing control mechanisms. However, it also became obvious that communication via Facebook, which simultaneously informed many people about a need, also limited the coordination of activities. In Case 2, looters became a problem, threatening the idealized image of a friendly, positive, flexible, and reliable organization. Consequently, the organizers and administrators continuously removed requests for assistance from the public Facebook communication, and informed the relevant volunteers about their orders by telephone.

In the second phase, the volunteers began to utilize physical spaces in addition to digital ones, to establish routines to enable intensive interactions and information flows between the center and its helpers on the periphery. In Case 1, the team leaders were asked to report a planned activity a day in advance, specifically on where and how many of a team would be active in which area on the actual day. This gave the organization a better idea of the on-site needs. In Case 2, the volunteers established a scouting system: Someone drove to the deployment sites and reported back to the core team about the extent to which these sites required specific equipment. The core team then made sure the SVs arrived with the exact equipment. In Case 3, the coordinating team often referred volunteers to local relief forces and encouraged them to ask for specific information regarding what was needed.

In Case 4, the authorities gave the SVs a discarded public transportation bus to act as an onsite “office.” Volunteers emphasized that the bus allowed their self-structuring to emerge. “Then the bus was really the central office, and from there all the things were coordinated” (Interview 4.1, p. 13). The SVs’ close proximity to the central station implied equal legitimization with other locally installed disaster relief organizations. Within days, social media communication became the responsibility of a single Facebook group. In Case 5, the volunteers organized a hall to collect and further distribute donated clothes, blankets, food, and hygiene articles. This physical space soon became a focal coordination point and one for exchanging information between the SVs and relief forces. In all the cases, meeting spaces were established where volunteers—coordinating teams and coordinated “helpers” —could come together and interact directly. Meeting spaces were equally important for developing and maintaining a sense of community, and also for fostering a collective identity within the various groups.

Symbols

Wearing identical clothing and recognizable accessories as a uniform, i.e., wearing symbols, became a strong instrument in terms of the volunteers’ membership negotiations and institutional positioning, in that these symbols drew visible boundaries around the emerging organization. Such symbols created a new sense of community. On the one hand, this created equality with disaster relief organizations, thereby granting the SVs subliminal legitimacy. On the contrary, the uniforms helped the SVs develop a common identity, making their performance capacity visible. In Case 1, volunteers began to wear recognizable clothing to distinguish themselves from other citizens. In Case 4, the authorities similarly required the volunteers to wear vests to control the maximum number of volunteers on the site. This requirement established an unintentional authority, because: “The moment, you put on a vest, ten [volunteers] were already around you and said, ‘Okay, what should I do?’” (Interview 4.1, p. 15). Over time, the volunteers’ roles and abilities were labeled on their vests, which allowed the quick identification of role holders. In Case 5, volunteers used self-made logos on their clothing or, later, on their uniform T-shirts to allow the current role holders to be identified.

Support

Other organizations, such as private companies, provided increasing access to resources, resulting in the organization’s capacity to act being scaled up. This capacity made it more difficult for other organizations and citizens to ignore the SVs’ activities, thereby promoting their pragmatic legitimization and establishing their agency. This also made it difficult for the authorities and relief forces to ignore the collective, and drove them to undertake coordination efforts.

To have sufficient resources available, the emerging organizations depended on (a) having enough members, (b) obtaining sufficient donations, and (c) collaborating with organizations that could provide equipment and materials and visibility (media).

By forming external partnerships, the volunteers in Case 2 increased their access to the necessary equipment. They received materials from disaster relief organizations, despite the lack of official regulations. “They [the relief forces] would say . . . we are not allowed [. . .] but you can just come to the station and see if there is anything in the trash right now” (Interview 2.1, p. 11). Conversely, in Case 1, the collective collaborated off the record with the city, which provided it with resources, such as vests and gloves.

In Case 3, it was clear that the high number of SVs, who were everywhere in the city area—blocking roads with their cars, and obstructing the relief vehicles—endangered the relief forces’ operation. The latter provided the volunteers’ coordinators with an office and a separate hotline, and also with a parking lot and transportation to the site to facilitate the coordination. In Case 4, the disaster relief organizations included the volunteers in the official briefings. Sometimes they even reposted or retweeted the SVs’ posts. This encouraged the volunteers’ self-structuring and once again added to their legitimacy.

Support, whether informal by administration and relief forces (Cases 1 and 2) or officials (Cases 3, 4, and 5), increased the SVs’ legitimacy and allowed them to be positioned as capable and relevant organizations. However, unofficial support from relief forces led to the volunteers developing a rather competitive identity toward the relief forces and authorities.

By supporting the SVs, the relief forces and the authorities created an opportunity for them to jointly manage the situation. The reciprocity of the support and its implications in terms of its legitimacy is clear: Neither the relief organizations nor the authorities could lock the SVs out, and the SVs’ involvement did not make the situation more chaotic.

Although each case’s context was unique, in all cases the 3 S facilitated the organizationality. However, the SVs’ legitimacy was justified differently in the refugee crisis cases than in the weather-related cases. While all the SVs justified their involvement by pointing out that the relief forces were overburdened, the SVs in the refugee crisis also argued that the response organizations were fundamentally not the appropriate stakeholders to deal with the crisis. Detailed case descriptions and a more in-depth cross-case comparison are presented in Supplementary Materials 4 and 5.

Figure 2 shows the model for organizationality in socially fluid collectives enhanced by the 3 S.

Figure 2.

Space, Symbol, and Support and Their Influences on Increasing Organizationality.

We learned from the cases that space is particularly important for the formation of structure, which is why space was mapped between the first and second phases. Symbols have an identity-building effect within an organization but also form the organization’s boundary. At the same time, they convey an image of the organization to the social context. As the communication of symbols already presupposes a structure—at least a common communication structure to support commitment to the symbol—we specifically observe symbols’ role in the evolution from Phase 2 to Phase 3. Finally, support allows the creation of a structure, as it specifically shapes an organization’s performance capacity, which has a specific impact on the organization’s identity and legitimacy. Individual practices of providing structuring and space for individuals in a chaotic setting contribute to organizational awareness. Increased organizationality facilitates the mobilizing of further support and the creation of organizational symbols, thereby enabling a collective identity and achieving legitimacy.

Discussion

Our comparative case study involves the traceability of an organization’s communicative emergence, by applying and complementing the 4 F model. The 4 F model allows us to focus on different communication flows. It becomes clear that in four of the five cases (Cases 1, 2, 4, and 5), the communication flow activity coordination was most pronounced in the beginning. Applying the 4 F model directed our attention to four relevant communication processes that allowed a deeper understanding of how organizationality is achieved and how an organization eventually emerges. While the 4 F approach is restricted to human communication (Iverson et al., 2018), our extension emphasizes materiality’s role in the form of the 3 S, i.e., space, symbols, and support, to achieve organizationality. Enhancing the 4 F model with the 3 S allows a better understanding of the crucial impact of the 3 S on fluid collectives’ organizationality.

Our research indicates that the structuring of space, mobilizing/granting support, and the creation of symbols play an important role in the communicative beginning of organizational forms and in achieving organizationality. This is in line with current research, where the role of social address, contributorship, and material configurations were identified as stabilizing in otherwise fluid organizational contexts (Berthod et al., 2021; Schoeneborn et al., 2022). Our findings emphasize that these factors contribute jointly to the development of a collective identity. Our research shows that space and practice affect each other reflexively and that this relationship contributes to organizationality and emerging SV organizations. In the context of the crisis, it becomes clear that not only SVs, but also stakeholders, such as relief forces, contribute through their support to the increasing organizationality. Our findings also underpin Harris’ et al. (2017) findings that the attitude of the relief forces is relevant for cooperative interaction.

With a higher degree of organizationality, other stakeholders perceive SV collectives as a legitimate form of organization. Contrary to prior research, we found that only in Case 3 was organizationality achieved as a result of a strategic act, whereas in the other cases it resulted from operational necessity (Schoeneborn et al., 2022). Supplementary material 6 highlights features of organizationality according to Schoeneborn et al. (2022).

As such, our findings are in line with organizational research on space’s and co-location’s role in emerging organizationality (Blagoev et al., 2019; Cnossen, 2021; Cnossen & Bencherki, 2019; Endrissat & Islam, 2022). Our findings also confirm the role of social media and specifically online platforms, such as Facebook, for the emergence of loose collectives (Jurgens & Helsloot, 2018; Kavada, 2015). Collectives use online and offline spaces to manage organizational boundaries (Grothe-Hammer, 2019). Supplementary material 7 presents identified practices in the five cases. Experiences during the COVID-19 pandemic also showed that using an online platform to share information and match needs is a powerful tool with the potential to circumvent or even replace insufficient institutionalized approaches (Burke et al., 2023; Spear et al., 2020; Trautwein et al., 2020).

We demonstrate that organizationality is achieved in three phases—the forming, structuring, and identity phases—thereby contributing to the understanding of organizationality’s temporality. The cases originate from a phase of activity coordination without structure, characterized by chaos and inefficiency. To facilitate coordination and enable a more meaningful contribution, individuals initiate structuring and coordinating activities. Although several of the associated activities could start in parallel, one structuring activity prevails over the others, which is consistent with Kornberger et al.’s (2019) results. The trial and error of different structuring activities characterize the second phase, while in the third phase, SVs developed practices to claim agency and to position themselves within the interorganizational context, which gives the external parties (media, cooperation partners) and the SV collective a broad awareness of the SV organization.

Our findings show that the volunteers developed a coherent collective identity very quickly. This collective identity is traceable in practices but also in discourses and in tangible symbols (Brown, 2021; Hardy et al., 2005). Accordingly, we argue that the 3 S (re-)produced and enacted the collective identity. Discursive routines and practices, which allow the emerging organization to be distinguished from others, stabilize the collective identity continuously. Wearing uniform clothing made the volunteers recognizable and enacted the membership boundaries. Their recognizability ensured that their institutional positioning within the social context materialized, thereby increasing the SVs’ legitimacy. This finding is in line with existing research (King et al., 2011; Patvardhan et al., 2015).

Legitimacy to act emerged as an important topic in all the cases. Measures, such as delegating, establishing requirements for certain tasks, and creating lines of responsibility, enabled the collectives to repeatedly achieve consistent results, giving rise to their legitimacy. SVs saw themselves as legitimate collectives, as they found that an SV collective reacts better, faster, and more flexibly to citizens’ or refugees’ needs than relief forces. The authorities and other organizations granted the SVs legitimacy by supporting practices and communication, such as referring to the SV collective as an organization in official reports (Case 1), by providing space (Case 3), or by their joint briefing sessions (Case 4), all of which are ways of talking the SV into existence as an organizational form. This confirms Schoeneborn and Scherer’s (2012) argument. Also, McPhee and Iverson (2009) found that institutional positioning is “chief and primordial” in its ability to obtain required resources (p. 83). Our research complements this finding and we argue that institutional positioning is strongly linked to legitimacy. An organization’s legitimacy allows resources to be obtained, while the organization simultaneously perpetuates its legitimacy through its resources.

From a practical perspective, our research provides scope for new approaches to collaborate with SV collectives in crisis settings. By emphasizing the important role of the 3 S, we highlight ways to promote SV collectives achieving organizationality. A higher level of organizationality enables and facilitates coordination in an interorganizational context. Instead of forcing an SV into relief forces’ structures or organizing appropriate occupations for them, relief forces can support SVs’ organizationality and self-coordination by creating a space for SVs or by providing material resources, such as vests or rooms. The cases show in an impressive way what SVs can do in a short time. The effective integration of resources into the relief effort is therefore useful, thereby avoiding some of the challenges of integrating SVs.

Limitations and Future Research

Our exploratory research design is based on five cases. To limit selection biases and bias due to retro-perspective interviews, we complemented our data with documents, videos, and social media communication. Interviewer effects were addressed by using semi-structured guidelines and having two interviewers when possible. We let interviewees choose interview locations and timing to reduce time and context bias. To minimize cultural bias, for example, we deepened our understanding of the work of high-reliability organizations prior to data analysis. We mitigated preconceived notions or theories by following systematic and transparent data analysis approaches as outlined in the methods section. As each case is situated in an extreme context, the transferability of our findings may be limited. We mitigated this limitation by conducting a multiple case study and by analyzing at least two cases from either a natural or a social context. Future research should extend our analysis to more cases and involve more stakeholders in the analysis. Accordingly, it may be relevant to shed more light on the courses of action available to relief forces. How can they contribute to keeping the chaos phase as short as possible? Or how can they determine which of several collectives is likely to reach the highest level of organizationality within a limited time frame? Finally, our research has only followed the emerging organizationality. Although we provide a brief overview of the aftermath for all cases, the question of sustainability arises with regard to future research: Why do some collectives continue to exist and, if so, which factors condition this process? Finally, research on extreme contexts provides insights into various management contexts (Hällgren et al., 2018). Thus, our model could be potentially beneficial for application in other settings, including grassroots political movements or patient communities for rare diseases (Budych et al., 2012).

Conclusion

Our article responds to earlier calls for a deeper understanding of fluid collectives achieving organizationality (Massa & O’Mahony, 2021; Schoeneborn et al., 2022) in varied contexts (Smith, 2022), and gaining legitimization (Nissen et al., 2022). Furthermore, it demonstrates how the 4 F model (i.e., the roles of membership negotiation, activity coordination, self-structuring, and institutional positioning) can be applied to trace fluid social collectives’ increasing organizationality and the communicative beginnings of emerging organizations. We extend the 4 F model to include the 3 S (i.e., the role of space, support, and symbols), thereby demonstrating materiality’s accelerating effect on organizationality. Our findings illustrate how organizationality can be a help in the handling of the inclusion/exclusion paradox of SVs (Harris et al., 2017) and thus how to support the role of SV collectives as potent partners in crisis response.

We show that, contrary to the hitherto dominant perception of being chaotic, SVs can emerge to be very structured collectives without being integrated into relief structures. Establishing trust in SVs and overcoming fear in reputational harm allows relief forces and authorities a more collaborative approach (Ruohonen & Backholm, 2023). Moreover, empowering SVs to achieve organizationality, for example, by providing space, and other resources could mitigate challenges linked to their integration (Simsa et al., 2019). In order for SVs to accomplish their work, incorporation into the structures and hierarchies of relief agencies does not seem necessary and may even hinder unbureaucratic and effective relief efforts.

2024 JUN 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on artificial intelligence. According to news originating from Selangor, Malaysia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Deep learning techniques through semantic segmentation networks have been widely used for natural disaster analysis and response. The underlying base of these implementations relies on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) that can accurately and precisely identify and locate the respective areas of interest within satellite imagery or other forms of remote sensing data, thereby assisting in disaster evaluation, rescue planning, and restoration endeavours."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia: "Most CNN-based deep-learning models encounter challenges related to the loss of spatial information and insufficient feature representation. This issue can be attributed to their suboptimal design of the layers that capture multiscale-context information and their failure to include optimal semantic information during the pooling procedures. In the early layers of CNNs, the network encodes elementary semantic representations, such as edges and corners, whereas, as the network progresses toward the later layers, it encodes more intricate semantic characteristics, such as complicated geometric shapes. In theory, it is advantageous for a segmentation network to extract features from several levels of semantic representation. This is because segmentation networks generally yield improved results when both simple and intricate feature maps are employed together. This study comprehensively reviews current developments in deep learning methodologies employed to segment remote sensing images associated with natural disasters."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Several popular deep learning models, such as SegNet U-Net, FCNs, FCDenseNet, PSPNet, HRNet, and DeepLab, have exhibited notable achievements in various applications, including forest fire delineation, flood mapping, and earthquake damage assessment. These models demonstrate a high level of efficacy in distinguishing between different land cover types, detecting infrastructure that has been compromised or damaged, and identifying regions that are fire-susceptible to further dangers."
For more information on this research see: Deep artificial intelligence applications for natural disaster management systems: A methodological review. Ecological Indicators, 2024,163():112067. The publisher for Ecological Indicators is Elsevier.

urn:contentItem:6CXD-8211-DY8S-B1JD-00000-00State, federal assessors find risks post Borel Fire2024-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:31:48ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSState, federal assessors find risks post Borel FirePETER SEGALLThe BakersfieldCalifornian

State and federal authorities have mostly completed hazard and risk assessments in the burn scar of the Borel Fire, which burned close to 60,000 acres in the last two months, making it the largest wildfire in Kern County history.

"The fire generally burned moderate with some areas of high in the upper elevations, particularly in areas that were dominated by more timber," said Don Lindsay, senior engineering geologist/geotechnical engineer with the California Geological Survey.

"Most of the hazards are focused along Havilah Canyon, the hazards there are predominately flooding hazards that would impact access by cutting off Havilah Canyon Road with overtopping flows," Lindsay said.

Lindsay was part of a state Watershed Emergency Response Team, or WERT, that was sent to Kern County to assess potential hazards and risks in the wake of the Borel Fire. WERTs are brought in to assess recently burned areas for risk associated with post-fire conditions such as flooding, debris flows and rock falls.

WERT plans are used by local agencies to determine response plans in the event of an emergency. The WERT team's plan is being reviewed by CalFire, said Drew Coe, a forester with the agency's watershed protection program.

"We classify the hazards. If you classify the hazards, then you’re more likely to come up with a more reasonable mitigation measure that might be effective," Coe said. "Then we make a basic relative risk call so that people can rank and sort of prioritize the implementation of emergency protective measures."

WERTs are the state side of the post-fire assessment process. Another similar assessment was done by an interagency federal team known as Burned Area Emergency Response, or BAER, which also recently completed its assessment of the Borel Fire, much of which burned on Forest Service land.

BAER teams create maps showing the burn severity of soil in the wake of a forest fire. How severely the soil is burned can impact the level of risk for events like debris flows and rock falls.

The BAER teams assessment of the Borel Fire found roughly 9% of the soil in the burned area to be considered high severity; 37% moderate; 49% low; and 5% very low or unburned.

"The more severe a fire’s effects are on the soil, the more likely those soils will erode in subsequent rainstorms — especially in locations with steep slopes," the BAER report said. "Erosion after fires can cause tremendous damage to homes and other structures in the years after a fire."

BAER assessments focus on federal lands and are mostly concerned with threats to human life and property, according to Todd Ellsworth, water program manager with the Forest Service.

"We're working with Kern County and identifying different values at risk downstream. We're also working on cleaning up some of the hazardous material," Ellsworth said.

Burned soil doesn't absorb water as well, and during rain events water runoff can build up and potentially turn into debris flows, fast-moving landslides of water, soil, rock and other objects disrupted by fire.

Debris flows are a risk following the Borel Fire, but not the dominant risk, according to Lindsay.

"I would say we have half a dozen residential structures that are at risk, a couple of which would be ranked at very high risk for both hazards to life and property," Lindsay said.

The biggest risk, according to Lindsay, is road access becoming blocked by flooding or debris.

"So the road network throughout the valley in and downslope of the burn scar is going to be stressed to say the least," Lindsay said. "We expect overtopping flows and loss of access during stressing storms."

One of the dangers that occurs in the wake of wildfires is that floods or landslides can be easily triggered by a small amount of rainfall. Changes in soil composition and loss of vegetation, particularly in areas with steep slopes, can cause rainfall to build up in ridges and gullies, potentially turning into a debris flow.

"This is kind of an arid environment and we have steep slopes that are burned at mostly moderate with some highs, those two factors combined can result in very low rainfall rates triggering flooding and also triggering debris flows," Lindsay said. "Generally, these hazards can be triggered by a storm event that’s expected to occur at least once every year."

Both the WERT and BAER teams have communicated their findings to the National Weather Service, which will monitor for potentially impactful rainfall events and issue warnings as necessary.

Post-fire rainfall can also create an environmental hazard as burned materials, particularly man-made ones, can get washed into streams and rivers, causing contamination of those water bodies.

Lindsay said there were a number of small defunct mines in the area, leftovers of the region's history of mining, that may cause increased amounts of metals to flow into local streams.

The state has teams that help to clear debris following a fire, and Kern County has been approved for the Office of Emergency Services phase 1 debris removal program.

Those teams were in the area Friday, according to Georgiana Armstrong, Kern County emergency services manager.

Phase 1 only removes visible household waste such as burned debris and wrecked cars. Phase 2 is a more in-depth process that includes removing contaminated soil, ash, hazardous trees and other remediation efforts. The county is still awaiting confirmation of phase 2 removal, Armstrong said.

The draft version of the WERT report has been shared with the county, and on Friday team members were meeting with county officials in the burn scar of the Borel Fire to discuss potential hazards.

Armstrong said the county would hold a series of meetings in the coming weeks to develop response plans.

"We’re on it, as best we can be. This is not something that’s being pushed aside," Armstrong said. "Recovering from the Borel Fire is front and center topic of ongoing importance."

AFP News

August 12th, 2024 ( International Business Times News - Delivered by Newstex )

A massive wildfire in Athens' northeastern suburbs on Monday forced thousands of residents to flee their homes and sparked a Greek government appeal for international help.

In unprecedented scenes in the Greek capital, residents wearing masks against the choking smoke were desperately dousing their homes with water hoses in the leafy suburbs of Nea and Palaia Penteli and Vrilissia to protect them from fire.

"(It's) the first time ever the fire has come here," said Melina Kritseli, 40, a civil servant living in a two-storey white house in Patima Halandriou, another Athens suburb that was evacuated.

"I took my children to a friend's house to be safe," she told AFP as her husband hosed the ground and grass outside their house.

Television footage showed several charred cars and the roofs of stately homes burning as water-bombing helicopters roared overhead.

Smoke drifted through central Athens as thick grey clouds engulfed Mount Pentelikon, which is known for yielding the marble used in the Acropolis and other ancient buildings.

The fire gutted a sports hall in Nea Penteli and many homes and businesses in the surrounding area.

The National Observatory, Greece's foremost institute monitoring natural hazards, narrowly escaped.

The Observatory website meteo.gr said 10,000 hectares (24,700 acres) had been devastated by midday Monday.

Greece on Monday formally called for EU assistance.

"The EU civil protection mechanism was activated upon request of the Greek authorities," EU spokesman Balazs Ujvari said in a statement.

He added that Italy, France, the Czech Republic and Romania were sending units to help.

"We stand with Greece as it battles devastating fires," EU commission chief Ursula von der Leyen wrote on X.

Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis had earlier cut short a vacation to Crete and returned to the capital Sunday.

The wildfire started on Sunday afternoon in the town of Varnavas, some 35 kilometres (22 miles) northeast of Athens.

Fanned by strong winds, it grew to a 30-kilometre long frontline of flames, more than 25 metres (80 feet) high in places, according to state TV ERT.

"I heard my animals bleating and dying," Dimitris Megagiannis, a goat herder near Palaia Penteli, told Mega TV station.

The fire department said over 700 firefighters with nearly 200 fire engines were trying to contain the fire, but dozens of water-bombing aircraft had to retire after dark.

Authorities opened the Olympic stadium in northern Athens and other sports facilities to house thousands of people evacuated from the path of the blaze. Three major hospitals have been placed on standby.

One firefighter suffered serious burns and another was hospitalised with breathing trouble, fire brigade spokesman Vassilis Vathrakogiannis said.

The health ministry said 66 people had been treated for injuries related to the fire since Sunday.

Several smaller communities and towns, including Marathon, started to evacuate on Sunday.

Several small clinics and hospitals in the area followed suit.

"Civil protection forces battled hard throughout the night, but despite superhuman efforts, the fire evolved rapidly," Vathrakogiannis said.

The wind had rekindled the fire in 40 different locations on Monday, he said.

The destruction revived memories of the disaster in Mati, the coastal area near Marathon where 104 people died in July 2018 in a tragedy later blamed on evacuation delays and errors.

The summer wildfire season in Greece this year has seen dozens of daily blazes after the Mediterranean country recorded its warmest winter and the hottest June and July since reliable data collection began in 1960.

The National Observatory said temperatures of up to 38 degrees Celsius (100 Fahrenheit) are expected in Athens on Tuesday, with winds of up to 39 kilometres (24 miles) per hour.

"Forest fire near you. Follow the instructions of the authorities," said SMS messages sent to people in the Attica region, indicating in which direction to flee.

Civil Protection Minister Vassilis Kikilias issued a warning Saturday that half the country faced a high risk of fires due to high temperatures, strong winds and drought conditions.

On Monday he said the fire had spread even though a water-bombing aircraft reached the area within five minutes.

"We're working 24-hour shifts, all of us," said fireman Marinos Peristeropoulos.

"The fire spread very quickly because of the strong wind," he told AFP near one of the hotspots in Grammatiko.

Scientists say that human-induced fossil fuel emissions are worsening the length, frequency and intensity of heatwaves across the world.

Rising temperatures are leading to longer wildfire seasons and increasing the area burnt in the flames, according to the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

Other parts of Europe are also struggling with high temperatures.

Parts of France rose above 40C on Sunday. In Rome, temperatures were forecast to reach 38C Monday and remain around 36C this week.

The following information was released by the Government of India:

India achieved Milestone of Planting 102 Crore Trees Under 'Ek Ped Maa Ke Naam' Campaign, aiming for 140 Crore by March 2025

Ministry notified the Eco-mark Rules on 26th September, 2024

National Clean Air Programme (NCAP) hit Milestones: 40% PM Reduction in 23 Cities, a,11,200 Crore fund allocated for Pollution Control; PRANA Portal launched for Real-Time Air Quality Monitoring

MISHTI launched on World Environment Day 2024 to Restore Mangroves and Boost Coastal Sustainability

13 beaches across 6 States and 3 Union Territories certified with Blue Flag Certification for the season 2024-2025
